Package algorithms.statistics

Class MultivariateDistance

java.lang.Object
algorithms.statistics.MultivariateDistance
public class MultivariateDistance extends Object
methods for calculating multivariate distance covariance and testing for independence. TODO: consider adding another method for High-Dimensional Independence Testing: Shen 2020, "High-Dimensional Independence Testing and Maximum Marginal Correlation", https://arxiv.org/pdf/2001.01095.pdf
Author:
nichole

  • Method Details

    • efficientDCov

      public static double efficientDCov(double[][] x, double[][] y, int k) throws NoSuchAlgorithmException
      calculate the distance covariance using the average of fast univariate distance covariances of random projections. 
            following the algorithm
      “A Statistically And Numerically Efficient Independence Test Based On 
      Random Projections And Distance Covariance”, 
      2017, Cheng Huang, And Xiaoming Huo, Annals of Statistics
      https://arxiv.org/pdf/1701.06054.pdf
     
           runtime complexity is O(n * K * log_2(n))
     (more specifically: O(n * K * (log_2(n) + p + q)))
     where k is the number of random projections and n is the sample size.
     memory requirement is O(max{n, K}).
      NOTE: there is material from the paper by Huang and Huo, and more that is related to it that is in the thesis of Huang: "Some computationally efficient methods in statistics and their applications in parameter estimation and hypotheses testing" https://smartech.gatech.edu/bitstream/handle/1853/60120/HUANG-DISSERTATION-2017.pdf
      Parameters:
      x - multivariate variable where the columns are the variates and rows are the samples.
      y - multivariate variable where columns are the variates and rows are the samples.
      k - the number of random projections
      Returns:
      distance covariance
      Throws:
      NoSuchAlgorithmException

    • efficientDCov

      public static double efficientDCov(double[][] x, double[][] y, int k, SecureRandom rand)
      calculate the distance covariance using the average of fast univariate distance covariances of random projections. 
            following the algorithm
      “A Statistically And Numerically Efficient Independence Test Based On 
      Random Projections And Distance Covariance”, 
      2017, Cheng Huang, And Xiaoming Huo, Annals of Statistics
      https://arxiv.org/pdf/1701.06054.pdf
     
           runtime complexity is O(n * K * log_2(n))
     (more specifically: O(n * K * (log_2(n) + p + q)))
     where k is the number of random projections and n is the sample size.
     memory requirement is O(max{n, K}).
      NOTE: there is material from the paper by Huang and Huo, and more that is related to it that is in the thesis of Huang: "Some computationally efficient methods in statistics and their applications in parameter estimation and hypotheses testing" https://smartech.gatech.edu/bitstream/handle/1853/60120/HUANG-DISSERTATION-2017.pdf
      Parameters:
      x - multivariate variable where the columns are the variates and rows are the samples.
      y - multivariate variable where columns are the variates and rows are the samples.
      k - the number of random projections
      rand - instance of secure random number generator
      Returns:
      distance covariance

    • fastDCor

      public static double[][] fastDCor(double[][] x1, double[][] x2)
      calculate the correlation matrix between the data for variables in x1 and x2 where x1 is a dataset of size [nSamples, nVariables1] and x2 is a dataset of [nSamples, nVariables2]. the resulting correlation matrix is size [nVariables1 X nVariables2]. 
           The runtime complexity is ~ O(m * p * n^2 * log_2(n))
         where m1 = x.length, n = x1[0].length, p = x2[0].length

     (In contrast a brute force correlation on matrices x1 and x2 has runtime complexity O(m^3*p*n^3 + m*p*n^4)
     
           example use:
         x1 = [300 X 9] dataset of 300 samples of 9 variables.
         x2 = [300 X 3] dataset of x1 projected onto 3 principal axes.
         dCor = [9X3] fastDCor(x1, x2) correlation matrix to look at the correlation of the principle axes
            with each variable from x1.

     This algorithm follows
 "A fast algorithm for computing distance correlation"
 2019 Chaudhuri and Hu, Computational Statistics And Data Analysis,
 Volume 135, July 2019, Pages 15-24.

     For speculation on comparing distance correlation values to the linear Pearson correlation,
     see Edelmann, Dominic and Móri, Tamás and Szekely, Gabor. (2021).
     On relationships between the Pearson and the distance correlation coefficients.
     Statistics and Probability Letters. 169. 108960. 10.1016/j.spl.2020.108960.

     TODO: consider making a faster version of this correlation.
      Parameters:
      x1 - dataset where each column is x1.length samples of a variable. note that x1.length must be equal to x2.length.
      x2 - dataset where each column is x2.length samples of a variable. note that x2.length must be equal to x1.length.
      Returns:
      correlation matrix between variables in x1 and x2 correlation values furthest from 0 are the most strongly correlated if any.

    • areIndependent1

      public static boolean areIndependent1(double[][] x, double[][] y, int k, int nIterations, double alpha) throws NoSuchAlgorithmException
      test for independence of x and y using permutations of y (approximating the null distribution) and the efficient dCov as a statistic. 
            following the algorithm
      “A Statistically And Numerically Efficient Independence Test Based On 
      Random Projections And Distance Covariance”, 
      2017, Cheng Huang, And Xiaoming Huo, Annals of Statistics
     
           runtime complexity is
      Parameters:
      x - x.length must be .geq. 20
      y - x.length must be .geq. 20
      k - the number of random projections for each test statistic.
      nIterations - the number of iterations for statistic calculations (note that each iteration constructs a new permutation of y, so this step has runtime complexity O(y.length * y[0].length)
      alpha - significance level for testing null hypothesis
      Returns:
      true if x and y are independent of one another
      Throws:
      NoSuchAlgorithmException - thrown if a random algorithm cannot be found

    • areIndependent1

      public static boolean areIndependent1(double[][] x, double[][] y, int k, int nIterations, double alpha, SecureRandom rand)
      test for independence of x and y using permutations of y (approximating the null distribution) and the efficient dCov as a statistic. 
            following the algorithm
      “A Statistically And Numerically Efficient Independence Test Based On 
      Random Projections And Distance Covariance”, 
      2017, Cheng Huang, And Xiaoming Huo, Annals of Statistics
     
           runtime complexity is
      Parameters:
      x - x.length must be .geq. 20
      y - x.length must be .geq. 20
      k - the number of random projections for each test statistic.
      nIterations - the number of iterations for statistic calculations (note that each iteration constructs a new permutation of y, so this step has runtime complexity O(y.length * y[0].length)
      alpha - significance level for testing null hypothesis
      rand - random number generator
      Returns:
      if true, x and y are consistent with independent, else if false x and y are not consistent with independent.

    • areIndependent2

      public static boolean areIndependent2(double[][] x, double[][] y, int k, double alpha) throws NoSuchAlgorithmException
      NOT READY FOR USE, instead use method areIndependent1(). test for independence of x and y using threshold of an approximate asymptotic distribution 
            following the algorithm
      “A Statistically And Numerically Efficient Independence Test Based On 
      Random Projections And Distance Covariance”, 
      2017, Cheng Huang, And Xiaoming Huo, Annals of Statistics
     
            The authors note that this assymptotic dependence test has less power for 
      low dimensional dependency in high dimensional data.
      One workaround may be to perform dimension reduction before using this method.
      For dimension reduction, see CURDecomposition class, and methods in
       "Learning Eigenfunctions Links Spectral Embedding
        and Kernel PCA", etc.
      Parameters:
      x - x.length must be .geq. 20
      y - x.length must be .geq. 20
      k - the number of random projections for each test statistic.
      alpha - significance level for testing null hypothesis
      Returns:
      true if x and y are independent of one another
      Throws:
      NoSuchAlgorithmException - thrown if no random algorithm can be found

    • areIndependent2

      public static boolean areIndependent2(double[][] x, double[][] y, int k, double alpha, SecureRandom rand)
      NOT READY FOR USE, instead use method areIndependent1(). test for independence of x and y using threshold of an approximate asymptotic distribution 
            following the algorithm
      “A Statistically And Numerically Efficient Independence Test Based On 
      Random Projections And Distance Covariance”, 
      2017, Cheng Huang, And Xiaoming Huo, Annals of Statistics
     
            The authors note that this assymptotic dependence test has less power for 
      low dimensional dependency in high dimensional data.
      One workaround may be to perform dimension reduction before using this method.
      For dimension reduction, see CURDecomposition class, and methods in
       "Learning Eigenfunctions Links Spectral Embedding
        and Kernel PCA", etc.
      Parameters:
      x - x.length must be .geq. 20
      y - x.length must be .geq. 20
      k - the number of random projections for each test statistic.
      alpha - significance level for testing null hypothesis
      rand - random number generator
      Returns:
      true if x and y are independent of one another
